text: Love the artwork on the label (bonus pts), clear golden, loads of vanilla in the nose, not much else. Hmmmm, I get vanilla, but not much else, a bit sweet, creamy however doesnt really strike me as a complex beer with layers, just a vanilla flavored cream ale. I dont get much (if any) coffee except a bit in the follow and aftertaste. One of the misses in a plethora of hits from Ballast Point.
Bottle. Light gold pour with a white head. Apparently sometimes putting lipstick on a pig does help. I dont like cream ales at all, but this was tolerable due to a nice dose of coffee and vanilla.
This was terrible. For me, at least. Vanilla is a great flavor, I love vanilla, but in a light bodied beer it basically sucks, its too dominant. Add cream and its undrinkable. Did not finish.

This is perhaps the only cream ale Ive had that was any good. Nice afomas of vanilla, light coffee, some milk/cream and nuts. The flavors are along the same lines but a little more muted. The body is pretty thin (as expected) with a slightly bitter finish. It pours a bright golden hue with a frothy white head.
Bottle. Medium golden hue. Prominent capsicum coffee and light vanilla cookie, mildly bitter finish. Not bad.

text: Draft. Amber beer with a cream head. Coffee aroma. Malt and vanilla flavor with coffee and light citrus. Medium bodied. Vanilla and light coffee linger with light citrus.

Poured from a 12oz brown bottle into a tulip glass, golden amber with weak white foam. Unimpressive golden ale base with gross vanilla and cold-steeped coffee notes, not at all harmonious. Artificial chemical taste. I really, really hated this disgusting stuff.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Aroma is coffee, vanilla, and some malt. Taste is sweet.

This draft brew from a restaurant poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a very softly carbonated transparent orange colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was malt hop. crisp with a lingering mild hoppy aftertaste. The ok flavor contained notes of wheat sweet grass crisp hops malt and bread dough. An OK brew just nothing special.

At first this seemed like an average blandish cream ale. Then after a few sips the coffee and cocoa nibs settled in. Has a semi-creamy texture, though I prefer even more. The coffee addition really helps, though without this doesnt really seem like a Ballast Point quality brew. Glad I tried a single that a buddy gave me...but would pass on full 6.
Flaska på Bishop Gustav, Malmö. Smak och doft av vanilj, kokos, grädde med fina kaffearomer. Fin sötma, bra aromer, krämig, rund och len med fin beska. Gott!

Bottle (as cream ale with coffee and vanilla), (from beergium). Pours amber. Aroma is coffee, beans, vanilla. Flavor is sweet and bitter, vanilla, malt, some coffee. Body is watery. Easy to drink. Overall: ok, but too thin.

Bottle shared by Mart, thanks! Clear orange amber beer, white head. Nose is coffee, malty sweetness, hints of caramel and vanilla. Flavor is coffee, vanilla, caramel, malt. Some hops in the finish with yet more vanilla.

330ml bottle (thanks Mart). Clear deep amber color. Small size, white head, stays. Coffee, vanilla, sweet in aroma. Vanilla and coffee in taste. Reminds me bit of molten ice cream. I wonder how the base beer tastes.

Clear, golden color with off-white head. Aroma has green coffee beans, some vanilla and also a slight acrid/acidic note. Taste starts with cacao beans and fresh vanilla beans, some acidity that maybe comes from the coffee or even the malts, but its not really bothering. Very balanced overall, neither sweet nor bitter. Light body with crisp carbonation. Overall its an interesting beer but the coffee and vanilla dont really mix so well with such a light beer.
Flaska på Bishop Gustav, Malmö. Fin frisk cream ale med mycket tevlig kaffesmak, lite gräddig och en aning vanilj kombinerar fint. Riktigt gott.

355ml bottle pours a slightly hazy golden orange color with a finger of white head that leaves some spotted lacing on the glass. Aroma is dominated by coffee with some caramel and hints of vanilla. Taste is a coffee bitterness with a caramel malty sweetness finishing a little dry with hints of vanilla. Light to medium bodied with adequate carbonation. Overall, a solid brew that is well crafted. Recommended for those who enjoy coffee.

Bottle.
Clear gold with an average white head.
Light coffee aroma. 
The flavor is lightly sweet with coffee and vanilla milkshake. No real hop flvor or aroma here. Spritzy light body. Not bad.

Best cream ale Ive ever had. Nice aroma with coffee and vanilla bean aroma. A pinch of spice with lactose up front. Mild malt profile with a bit of sweetness on their finish. Smooth and rich. Nice brew.
On tap at Cottonwood. Pours a hazy copper with medium creamy white head that lasts. The aroma is roasted nuts, spice, cocoa. Medium body, hazelnuts, cocoa, light finish, very good.
Draft at Ballast Point. Aroma of creamy vanilla and coffee. Taste has soft creamy vanilla, coffee and a malt note. Very tasty.
Bottle. Notes of vanilla, malt, bread and metal. A pretty good drink. Spice, anise and coffee as well. You can really notice the fresh water used to make it. Sharp.
Bottle from beergium. Hazy dark gold color. Thin white head. Light sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium crispy body. Finish is dry and medium. Aroma is coffee, cacao, vanilla, light fruit.

355 ml bottle. Pours a clear orange-golden with little white foam. Intense aroma of vanilla, coffee and pipe tobacco. The taste is medium sweet with a light bitterness. Full body with a slick mouthfeel and nearly no carbonation. Flavours of Vanilla, pipe tobacco, licorice. Strong and pretty unique character and a nice brew.
On tap at Einsteins Pub. Golden with a frothy white head. Aroma of coffee and cream soda. Taste is light with a little coffee and sweetness. Light-medium bodied and smooth.

Calm Before The Storm versa nel bicchiere di colore giallo dorato, molto chiaro; la schiuma è bianca a grana fine, non è molto pronunciata, ma lascia comunque un leggero strato persistente. Al naso è piena di aromi di caffè, sostenuti da sentori di vaniglia, note cremose e di malti dolci. In bocca vengono confermate le percezioni nasali: attacco sorprendentemente fresco di caffè, cui fanno seguito sapori di vaniglia, ben amalgamati a leggeri sentori di malto tostato. Rimane una birra liscia e mai astringente, dal corpo medio e da una carbonazione non elevata; solo nel retrogusto si avverte un delicato amaro, per una leggera sensazione di secchezza.
Bottle from K&B. Coffee up front with a bit of a sour flavor to it. Somewhat watery. Decent ale but lacking richness in the flavor and body. Not a lot of vanilla. Mild coffee. A little too watery.

375ml bottle.
Roasted coffee aroma with damp earth overtones.
Light amber color with good head and lacing.
Mild bitterness followed by a strong roasted coffee character and a slight creamy vanilla finish.
OK.
Draught at monks café. Pours golden with a small white head. Aroma is full of cream. Taste is really creamy with Caramel notes.

Draft at monks 
Clear, yellow, small white head
Bachelorette party. 
Aroma of cream dusty

12 oz. appears it was bottled 08/19/2016. Pour is clear amber with a spongy foam on top. Nose is toasted walnut, coffee with cream, and toasted bread. Tastes of vanilla, toast, chocolate and toasted nut. Really tastes like a Little Debbie Nutty Bar with some coffee on the finish. Near medium bodied with smooth medium carbonation. Coffee provides a decent balance to the sweetness.

Clear brilliant deep golden under a thin white cap. Lovely nose of big blonde roast coffee and lactose sugar and light earthy vanilla. Smooth and earthy flavor that features that lactose sugar creaminess prominently with a big bit of coffee and a fair deal of earthy vanilla, and a earthy crisp finish. Its all very earthy roasty coffee but also creamy and sugary. Its strange but I like it.
Clear gold with no head; aroma is malty grainy; flava is sweet notes of vanilla and coffee; feels Medium silky smooth soft fizz; finishes sweet yet mildly dry

I dont know that Ive ever had a Coffee Cream Ale. Coffee stouts and porters, yeah, sure, plus the occasional Coffee IPA, but not this style. Anyhoo, I liked it. Notes of fresh coffee up front, then subtle citrus and vanilla. Dryish finish. On tap at Bearden Beer Market.
Bottle in Las Vegas. Clear golden pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of coffee, vanilla, caramel and some grains. Flavor is quite sweet malty and with a thick body. Decent balance.

Golden and clear with a frothy white head. 
Coffee, roasted nuts, and vanilla aromas. 
Starts with bitter and sour coffee flavors but finishes with sweet vanilla coffee flavor. Average carbonation. 
Coffee, vanilla flavor.

Bottle. Pours a copper color with white head. Coffee, vanilla, honey, sweet, malty, creamer aromas. Coffee, vanilla, slight bitter, slight metallic flavors. Light-medium bodied. Almost is really good, but flavor is just slightly off.

This cream ale poured a clear medium Amber colour with a beautiful creamy, bright white head. Scents of coffee, hops, light vanilla and cream most prominent. First swig was quite crisp. A little thinner than expected but very good none the less. Flavours of coffee and hops with a light vanilla flavour in the background. Finish is slightly bitter with coffee and vanilla lingering.
Bottle @ Man in the Moon, Stockholm. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and coffee. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 260716

Golden amber pour with a thin white head. Aroma is coffee that dominates the aroma. A hint of vanilla. Taste is coffee, closely followed by vanilla. Creamy mouth feel. Coffee bitterness. What a treat.

Aroma of cereal grains, vanilla, and cream. Taste is cereal grain, vanilla cream, and a nice burnt coffee flavors just on the back of the tongue.Earlier Rating: 5/12/2016 Total Score: 2.9Aromas of cereal malts, vanilla, and black pepper maybe. Taste starts out with cereal malts on the front of the tongue, then vanilla and cream build up all the way down your gullet. Pepper notes appear in the finish. Not really any coffee (bottle is 2 months old). After taste of cream, vanilla, and pepper.

On tap at 2865. It poured a golden color with a white head. The aroma was of coffee, vanilla and some honey. The taste was similar to the aroma with more coffee, vanilla, cookie dough and honey. Interesting.

A tasty treasure! Pours gold w/ a thin white head & some lacing. The aroma is a beautiful blend of coffee & vanilla & the taste is right on point. The coffee & vanilla flavors blend exquisitely! Its a complex, medium bodied offering that is a must try! Deliciousness!

"A coffee ale with a touch of cream." Ballast Point gets it right with that description - and they really get it right with how this beer is made. Clear gold pour. Earthy coffee aroma with subtle vanilla sweetness. The flavor starts of with coffee bitterness and ends with light creaminess. The coffee gives off a lovely brightness in this light-bodied beer. This usually isnt my style, but Calm Before the Storm is my kind of Cream Ale.
Dominated by the coffee and cream but still very light and easy. Wife really liked this one.

355ml bottle. Pours a clear golden with a medium, frothy, long lasting, off-white head that laces nicely. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, vanilla and roasted coffee. Sweet flavour of vanilla, caramel malt and biscuit with a dry, mildly bitter coffee finish. Medium body with a creamy, smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. Delicious. A world class cream ale.

Deep golden orange color pour, with a nice white foam cap. Coffee is the main event here and it works as good as any other stout, porter beer around. Aroma is of freshly ground coffee and a pleasant caramel like sweetness. The coffee flavor embraces the tongue right away with the smooth creamy body and medium carbonation. More milk caramel accompanies the taste, but its not overly sweet and still finishes a little dry. There is a slight hop presence but barely noticeable. Great beer all around.

Bottle.

A- Earthy coffee, bitter, roasty.

A- Golden orange color, clear liquid, off white head.

T- Earthy coffee, vanilla.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, mildly sweet finish.

O- Having had Victory at Sea, my expectations for this were unjustifiably high. Naturally, I was a bit disappointed but minus that it was a decent brew. I figured it would be a sweet flavor but it was definitely more earthy and dry. A fair amount of bell pepper and dirt on the nose and same one the palate with just a hint of vanilla sweetness on the finish. Good, but not quite Victory at Sea great. Needs more sweet espresso like coffee and more vanilla.

Pours clear golden with a large white head. Smells strongly of coffee and hints of vanilla. Taste is almost literally french vanilla coffee. Light-bodied with a wet texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Ballast Point Calm Before the Storm finishes bittersweet.

On tap. Pours a dark golden color with a small head and bits of lacing. Aroma of coffee, vanilla malt sweetness and grain. Taste of malt sweetness, vanilla and some coffee. Mild bitterness and a fairly clean finish. Moderate body, smooth with just enough coffee to take the edge off of the vanilla. Nice beer.

Bottle. Coffee aroma with notes of vanilla and lactose sugar. Pours clear golden colored with a thin, but retentive off white head that also has decent lacing. Starts with lactose sugary flavor with a creamy mouthfeel and a light body. Finishes a bit dry with roasty coffee and some vanilla flavors. A bit strange but it's a nice cream ale.
Pours a clear yellow-gold with light white head. A strong creamy coffee and vanilla aroma. Has a simple taste with coffee and some vanilla. A lingering sweet vanilla aftertaste.
On tap at griffon transit. Thick mouthfeel and coffee. Very good coffee inclusive. Fun stuff.caramel,

On tap at PIB 2016, pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma brings out lots of coffee and vanilla upfront. Flavour is along the same lines, with mostly coffee upfront, with subdued vanilla notes. Certainly doesnt hint at a cream ale, which is great. Solid stuff.
This beer has a bright pour with an aroma of coffee. Coffee through the flavor as expected. Its balanced and clean. Slightly sweet, not too creamy.
Draft - Nice roasty dark coffee. Clear gold with a rich white head. Nice roasty sweet notes, coffee and balance. Nice.

Appearance: Clear golden amber body with a frothy white head. Really appealing beer.
Aroma: Bit of confectioners sugar, vanilla, and a bit of coffee, balanced nicely with a pleasant aroma. Reminds me slightly of coffee with vanilla cake.
Taste: Mild tartness up front, sort of lemony, with a tangy presence throughout. Vanilla and coffee are noted, coffee is mildly astringent. Overall balance is great.
Palate: Medium to full mouthfeel, carbonation is expansive and soft.
Overall: A really nice treat to have after my morning run. Light enough to drink in the day, flavorful enough to be enjoyable.
Draught @ Cosmic Comic, Turku. Slightly hazy golden with a medium white head. Vanilla, coffee and cereal mostly. Creamy mouthfeel. Medium/high co2.
light coffee aroma with hints of vanilla; clear, amber color; coffee notes and hops on a medium bodied, bready malt base; light vanilla notes

Tasting session @ Budapest.
Slightly hazy yellow gold, white fluffy head. Cold pour coffee and vanilla nose. Medium light body, low carb. Vanilla and faint light coffee and cream. Sweetish finish. Fine.
clear gold color with no head. aroma is coffee with sweet vanilla creamer. flavor is coffee, vanilla, and some malt and spice.

Great smell of coffee, sweet malts and bit of lemon zest. Clear gold color with no head and no lacing. Me being a coffee lover love that nice rich Taste of the coffee sweet malts Come Thru in the middle sweet bitter finish. Flat like carbonation with a light body works out considering its a coffee Style Beer. Wish the carbonation was a little bit more spunky but love golden or light coffee beers and this really works. Nice work.

Pours a clear light gold with mucho foam that lasts and leaves lacing.

I smell vanilla, cocoa and coffee. Awesome aromas.

Coffee and cocoa up front and then some vanilla moves in. Not really sweet, very light bitterness from the coffee. Super easy to drink, especially with the lowish abv.

Too bad the 6 pack is over $14 or I would visit more often.
Had a sample at WOBFest 2016. Im usually a huge supporter of Ballast Points work, but this one falls a little flat.
Sweet light coffee malt aroma. Clear golden color with a medium white head. Moderate sweet beginning with a bitter coffee finish.

Reminds me of an imperial stout only this one is a cream ale. Pours a golden orange with small foam head. Aroma is of vanilla and coffee. Taste is slightly bitter with vanilla coffee finish. Feels creamy in the mouth. An interesting concept craft beer. I will drink it again

This is a tough one to rate. I was expecting a cream ale with a touch of vanilla and coffee, and this is - like the description states - a coffee ale with a touch of cream. I am not a fan of coffee. The aroma is coffee. Taste and aftertaste hits strong of coffee. After the initial taste where I get past the disappointment, the cream ale elements and vanilla come through. Moderate carbonation mixed with a creamy mouthfeel. 

Though, I am not a fan of this beer - due to my dislike of strong coffee flavors - I am rating this according to how I think they succeeded in creating what they wanted. I am not marking it down low due to my lack of knowledge I was getting a coffee beer

It pours golden orange with a large soapy off white head. The aroma has smooth coffee, pale malt, chocolate and vanilla. It has a light crisp body with lots of sharp carbonation. It starts off with dry cracker pale malt, spicy hops and some woodiness. There is coffee and vanilla there but it is more underlying than on top like the aroma. The finish has coffee bitterness and some hops bitterness, but pleasing, not abrasive. Really nice.

Bottle. Pours gold with a thin head that dissipates to a creamy lace. Aromas of coffee, black pepper and sweet corn; a bit of skunkiness. Flavors are fresh ground coffee, pepper, sweet corn, grass and biscuit. Light, slightly creamy mouthfeel. Medium carbonation. Subtle flavors. Not a lot of character. Interesting brew, but not terribly memorable.
Aroma of vanilla, coffee, taste is vanilla and coffee, very well balanced, nice bitterness from the coffee, would recommend.
12 oz bottle. Pours a golden color with a nice white head. Aromas of vanilla, coffee. Flavor of light roast coffee and vanilla. Medium bodied, creamy and very good.
Tap. Pours a darker gold. Aroma of coffee and cream. Taste is semi sweet. Tastes like cold, carbonated coffee with cream and sugar. Good enough.

On tap at Hops and Pie poured a clear golden amber with a small lasting ivory head. Aromas of coffee, bread and light vanilla. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a smooth dry finish. Flavors of bread, coffee and light vanilla with a smooth dry lingering coffee finish.

Bottle. Poured honey color. Medium white head that quickly dissipated. Aroma of coffee, marshmallows, and vanilla. Taste of black coffee and dark chocolate. Interesting beer. A nice coffee beer that is light and creamy.
A good cream ale with notes of coffee and vanilla pours with a nice 2 finger head good lacing, would recommend.
Bottle. Pour is a clear gold with a thin head and aromas of coffee (!!). Flavor is perfect for this style. Vanilla and coffee with happiness. Damn dude. Try it and tell me Im wrong.

text: Pours a golden orange/yellow. Aromas of floral, semi-sweet notes and a hint of coffee. Seemed sweet to me with a nice bitter end.
Great concept beer. Café Au Lait. Creamy vanilla spiked coffee beer. Sounds like Starbucks, but tasted really good, if not a bit mild. I guess that would be the cream ale speaking.

12oz bottle from the state store 
Pours clear golden with a medium sized white head, some lacing. Aroma of coffee and vanilla. Flavor of citrus, vanilla with a nice mild bitterness 
Nice

Nice aromas and flavors of vanilla, coffee and grain. Not much hops presence but the blend was nice. Nice color and mouthfeel. Cream ales tend to be boring but these additions amped it up a bit. Hope they make it more available.

At Ballast Point having it on tap. The recipe creator is sitting beside me. Cream ale infused with coffee and vanilla. Aroma is superb. Will drink it again.

Bottle shared by a friend. Pours clear gold with a medium beige head. Aroma of coffee, malt and vanilla. Malty flavor with vanilla sweetness before a roasty coffee finish.
Pours a yellow color with a foamy white head. Notes of heavy vanilla, flowers, roasted grains, and lingering smoke.

12 ounce bottle shared. The beer is a clear yellow with a white head of foam. The aroma has pleasant coffee notes, but there is some accompanying vanilla creaminess as well. Interesting flavor profile but just too much carbonation for coffee flavors.

Good beer quite refreshing, great smell of coffee as your pour it in the glass, beautiful color, you can taste the vanilla just a little bit at the end. Glad to tried it, never been disappointed with Ballast Point up to now, they experiment a lot witch it make it always fun and interesting to taste there products.
Sample @ PGH Beerfest. Deep amber color. Nice light coffee aroma. Semi-sweet creamy taste with a hint of coffee that isnt too overpowering. OK but not great.
Bottle shared by a friend during poker. I loved the coffee aromas. Wish the flavor had been more coffee and less of that classic cream ale boringness.
Todella kahvinen tuoksu, ei juuri muuta. Maussa on kermaisuutta, mutta muuten maku on vähän valju.

From 12oz bottle to shaker. Pour is a nice gold with a thick white head. Nose is coffee, chocolate, vanilla, malt. Taste is medium bodied, sweet. Finishes super smooth. Awesome beer, love the complexity for a cream ale.

Golden color, tan head fades quickly. Strong coffee aroma surprises, considering the color. Coffee taste, mixing with vanilla cream, then back to a burnt coffee flavor. Silky smooth, yet moderate carbonation. Easy drinking.
Appearance is medium white head with clear light orange color. Aroma is a used coffee filter. Taste is similar with some creaminess. Overall just not that great.

Bottle from bottledog Edinburgh. Slightly hazy yellow gold, white fluffy head. Cold pour coffee and vanilla nose. Medium light body, low carb. Vanilla and faint light coffee and cream. Sweetish finish. Fine.

Bottle in hotel room Orlando 2016... Amber... Thin creamy off white head.. Soft sweet vanilla fruits nose... Soft sweet fruits... Creamy malt.. Soft sweet vanilla.. Ligh spice linger.. Light dry mellow coffee finish

Draft to taster at Dutchs from notes. Pours a clear golden light orange color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have nice coffee character, mild plus vanilla, cereal malts, there is a creamy character to the flavor especially, some grainy malt, good flavor, one of the beers that visually is different than the flavor, interesting.

Shared 12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Aroma of coffee and vanilla. Taste is coffee, vanilla, and a little cream, with the coffee taking center-stage. Not bad, but not too exciting.
I like. Near clear yellow pour. Aroma is a little musty but nice. Taste is coffee and vanilla. I think I taste cinnamon.

Aroma: vanilla and coffee with an undertone of something I cant quite place; not entirely pleasant; Appearance: clear golden pour with fluffy head that dissipates fairly quickly; decent lacing Taste: aggressive vanilla with minor coffee in the background; more personality than the other cream ale weve had; Palate; medium body with medium, sweet finish; Overall: acceptable but too reminiscent of a cream soda trying to be a beer; would probably not buy again.
From a bottle. Pours a clear golden color. Aroma and taste are coffee, vanilla, and pale malts.

Draught (Monks American Bar, Stockholm) - Golden in colour. Coffee and vanilla (smells artificial) dominate in the aroma of this beer, and are also very recognisable in the taste along with some biscuity notes. Seems a bit gimmicky to me.

12 oz bottle. Pours a mostly clear golden yellow color and topped by a small layer of off white foam that settles quickly to a thin film and leaves nice rings of lacing. The aroma is nice showing notes of fresh roasted coffee, vanilla, cream, a bready malt base with some earthy bitterness on the back. The flavor follows with the fresh roasted coffee and cream up front to go with the vanilla and toasted bread malts. There is a nice balance between the sweet and bitter notes. Medium bodied with balanced carbonation that leads to a lengthy, sweet coffee and vanilla finish. This is a well done and tasty cream ale, and possibly the best in the style I have had.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Clear bright copper amber color, white head cover, spots of lace. Taste is creamed coffee and malt that gracefully coasts through a mild carbonated swallow to a finish with only a hint of hops. Leans toward the coffee and malt, but awfully easy to quaff.

(Keg at Viisi Penniä, 20160129) The beer poured amber and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had cream, malts and grass. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were creaminess, malts, grass, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste was creamy and bitter. If a brew choses to call itself as a cream ale this one should be the reference.

Pours a clean, golden yellow color from a bottle. Smells fantastic, I get vanilla, a little coffee, and cream. Tastes pretty good too, more vanilla than coffee and lots of cream. Almost too much. My only complaint about this is the mouthfeel, which is a bit too much after youre halfway through. Otherwise, best flavored cream ale Ive tasted.
Pours slightly hazy and amber with ample frothy head. Aroma is faint but smooth and sweet with nutty vanilla character. Flavor is light with warm bitter vanilla with a somewhat rubbery texture.
Bottle at Pub Winston. Clear golden color, small white head. Strong vanilla aroma. Essance-like. Light-bodied. Pale malts and vanilla. Some coffee. Interesting combination but not my cup of coffee.
Vähän oli teennäistä. Vanilja maistui paljon, mutta ei se ehkä vaaleaan olueseen kuulu.

12 oz. bottle purchased at 7 Eleven, Kittery ME. A few particles floating around in a mostly clear gold color. Aroma shows substantial coffee, light vanilla and malted wheat. 
Flavor has a great level of coffee upfront with the malted wheat as the base. Also has a light chocolate taste. The texture is indeed creamy with a great fullness over the tongue. Ballast point was able to take a plain style and give a ton of flavor. Love the bold coffee!!

Dark orange Amber pour, very occluded, a bit of white haze. Aroma of sweet apple and metallic hops, lots of vanilla, maple, a bit of bitter coffee. Soft carbonation, oily thick mouthfeel, crisp finish. Strong presence of lightly toasted coffee, caramel, subtle metallic hops, lots of vanilla really good cream ale.

Draught @ Stags Head. Clear rich yellow appearance with medium sized creamy whitish head, very faint malt aroma, low carbonation, slightly sweet malty taste, creamy body, medium malty finish with slightly hops bitterness. Very smooth and drinkable.

Restrained aroma in a golden pour. Laid back vanilla coffee flavors in an otherwise watery/thin malty body. Not one Id be looking to have another of. And just goes to show even the best brewers can miss the boat at times (its no Victory at Sea).

Draft at Churchkey. Crystal clear bright golden color, white head. Aroma has toasted brown bread, cocoa powder (a pleasant surprise), caramel. Taste has malted milk balls, malt forward. One of the tastiest cream ales Ive had.
Bottle from Beer and Wine. Hazy golden body with slight head. Nose is vanilla, spicy and caramel. Taste is malty, toasty, chocolate and caramel. Smooth, creamy texture. Nice and spicy. Creamy finish.

On tap at Man in the Moon. 

Golden with a white head. Aroma and taste of vanilla, some light roasted malt, caramel and light fruit. On the light side with low carbonation. A bit strange to be honest.
Its good but nothing really stands out that makes it above average. Good cream ale though.
Coffee aroma and upfront taste. Vanilla taste at end. Pales in comparison with the many fine coffee stouts.
Tap. Pours a hazy golden with beige head. Aroma and taste of coffee, toasty malts, some vanilla.

Aroma is indeed coffee with pale malts and slight earthy. Taste is a bit of a mindf**k, here we have this golden ale, and you dont expect coffee coming around to run the show, but it does. Vanilla shows up in the end to smooth things over, but I get some kind of sharp, unpolished side taste that I cant put my finger on. Strange? Yes. Experimental? Yes. Good? Well... I dont know?

Draft at Brixx Charlottesville. Pours golden with a thin white head. Doesnt leave much lacing in the glass. Lovely coffee notes on the tongue. Lots of coffee flavor and a bit of malt as well. Finishes clean. Really a nice beer especially given the style.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 9/22/2015. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy golden yellow color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big dark roasted coffee, cocoa, vanilla, cream, honey, cracker, bread, light pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance of coffee/vanilla, bready malt, and light earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of big dark roasted coffee, cocoa, vanilla, cream, honey, cracker, bread, light pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Light herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of roasted coffee, cocoa, vanilla, cream, honey, cracker, bread, and hebral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic robustness and balance of coffee/vanilla, bready malt, and light earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/silky, and slightly sticky mouthfeel that is awesome. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an outstanding coffee cream ale. All around awesome robustness and balance of coffee/vanilla, bready malt, and light earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.

Ballast Point Calm Before the storm on tap at Galmegi Haeundae. Crystal clear copper pour with an off-white head of foam. Big coffee & cream aroma thats quite nice. The taste is a bit on the sweet side but does give you the same solid sweet milk coffee flavor. Good stuff.  Kind of reminds me of Master of Disguise.

Pours clear golden with a low white head. Aromas of coffee,vanilla, slight smoked mest, orange, honey. Taste is smokey and nutty and quite sweet. Mouthfeel is light with medium carbonation. Very strange.

A clear orange body with small bits floating around, the white head disappears quickly. Nose has notes of vanilla, roasted malts and caramel. Taste is quite dry and roasty with a mellow finish. Low carbonation and medium palate. Interwsting beer with a large contrast between the sweet nose and roasty flavor.

Very nice dark gold/light brown color with thin head when poured. Coffee-dominant aroma, of course. Youll also get a bitter taste with the coffee yet the smoothness of a cream ale fights through a little. Higher than average carbonation with the coffee aftertaste. Not sure if Ill buy another six-pack of this but would order in bar or restaurant.
Bottle from whole foods, orlando. Amber color, white head. Aroma has malts, vanilla notes, some coffee and creamy notes. Malty body, caramel, coffee, vanilla. Pretty nice creamy pale ale.
Pours clear dark golden color with white head. Aromas of coffee and vanilla with some caramel. Slightly bitter coffee flavor with some vanilla. Medium body with average carbonation.

This just doesnt taste right to me. Subtle hints of vanilla in a dark, robust beer might be welcome-- but this is neither subtle nor dark and robust. Hints of some air freshener grade of vanilla dominate the nose. I wanted to like this more, but I just couldnt really get into it. This one is too weird and plasticky for me to enjoy.

Pours a clear golden brown on tap with fluffy off-white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma and taste of coffee and vanilla, mixed with malty sweetness and a touch of earthy hops. Really nice cream ale, with balanced adjuncts that make it delicious.
Probably the best cream ale Ive had. It reminds me of bean flicker except way better.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2015 Bottled. Clear Amber color with carbonation. Surprisingly coffee tasting for such a light beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled. One of the better cream ales Ive ever had. Pours new penny colored with a 1 finger firm head. Sweet aroma of coffee with vanilla cream, Good body, just the right amount of sweet malt and coffee mated well with soft vanilla.

L: pours a bright clear copper-bronze, with a tiny head that fizzes out. 
S: an aroma of milk up front, coffee creamer perhaps, or milk-flavoured candy. This turns into a total cream soda nose as it opens up. Lots of vanilla. 
T: ahh, theres the coffee. Quite a delicious strain too. But over time I get tired of the sweetness and cream soda quality. 
F: it is quite lively, and easy drinking, fizzy on the palate. 
O: it started out a unique and decent ale, but it had me wishing I was just drinking a tasty cream soda by the end. In Japan, Suntory recently put out a disastrous pumpkin ale; this feels like what they were aiming for.

Keg at Babajan, Stockholm.  Clear amber, small head. Caramelly vanilla aroma. Mid sweet with medium body and clean, hard mouthfeel. Metall, caramel, milk. Resinous metallic finish. Off-putting and edgy, almost like the Chinese Kefir Milk Beer. Undrinkable

Poured from bottle into a pint glass
 Appearance- The beer pours a medium golden amber color with a one finger head of white foam. The head has a decent level of retention, slowly fading over time to leave a good deal of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
 Smell  The aroma of the beer is weird. It has a sweet caramel smell mixed with a little bit of a green coffee smell. A decent showing of vanilla is there as well. Now these are really not all that weird in general, but with a mix of some other sweet cream soda and a bit of corn, the overall aroma is sweet, but vanilla flavored coffee like in nature. Its not bad, but just somewhat weird. 
 Taste- The taste begins with a rather strong bready flavor mixed with a decent creaminess and caramel flavor. A surge of more cream and vanilla come at the middle and take the taste to the end. That is where a little bit of a lightly roasted coffee taste hits the tongue. With more vanilla and some corn sweetness that comes to the tongue at the very end, one is left with a rather interesting light coffee and sweet crème taste to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel- The body of the beer is on the on the medium to thin side with a carbonation level that is slightly higher. For the crème ale style mixed with the light coffee and sweeter tastes, the feel was rather nice and made for a good easy drinking feel.
 Overall  This was an interesting one. I was not that fond of it at first sips, but it really grew on me more and more as I continued to drink it. It has a sorta odd flavor mix of crème, coffee, and sweet, which in some ways really works. Any which way, I would certainly recommend a try to anyone as it is somewhat unique in nature.

Bottled. Pours light cream, very clear, and you guessed it, creamy head. Aroma is cream soda, vanilla, a ton of coffee. Flavor is sweet, cream Soda, the coffee and vanilla both come through. Nice cream ale.

355ml Bottle from Brewdogs Online Shop (£4.00):
Not exactly what I was expecting, it was lighter anyway but still nice with some biscuit malts & roasted flavours plus an earthy hop base. The vanilla & coffee promised from the label are definitely the most dominant flavours with this one. There was a nice amount of sweetness coming through & the beer was quite a smooth & creamy one that was enjoyable but to be honest probably isnt one that Id be likely to go for again.

12 oz bottle. Deep gold and clear with an average ivory head. Aroma is of coffee, cocoa, vanilla bean, toast, and light herbal notes. Taste is of vanilla, sweet malts, chocolate, light black pepper, coffee.
Bottle. The look is clear, white head, and golden copper in color. The smell is chile, coffee, vanilla, cream, nice, latte, and not bad. The taste is coffee, sweet, roast, light. Ok.
Draft. Golden pour with white lacing. A lighter version of regular coffee, sweet and cream, light espresso aromas. Flavors have turned pepper, light espresso and cream sweetness.
Nice cream ale. Rich and creamy with deep vanilla, but not syrupy or overly sugary. Medium yellow color. Aroma is light, mostly cream. The coffee comes out at the end and is very even. Bottle

Aroma is coffee, vanilla, maybe light spice but a bit of wheat. Appearance is like an IPA, golden amber with an off white head. Taste is nice coffee and vanilla, finishes like a wheat ale, refreshing. Mouthfeel is crisp carbonation, light to medium body. Overall, the coffee and vanilla really saves this beer from being mediocre and even forgettable.

Clear, intense polished bronze beer. Stiff, lasting rocky head. Acidic ale and coffee aroma. Earthy, unripe, tannic flavor with hints of vanilla beans. To borrow a line from Arte Johnson, "Very interesting." Improved as it warmed -- sweetened and rounded out. Mouthy. Dusty vanilla finish. ABC Liquors, Betton.

This beer pours golden brown and smells a lot how it looks: like something steeped in coffee. Whats odd is that for me, all of the coffee notes are restricted to those two senses, as it doesnt taste like coffee so much as it smells and looks like it. Its got a rich taste, and its kind of heavy, and isnt something Id drink again knowing it isnt what I expected from something billed as a Cream Ale.

Pour on tap at HopCat, slightly hazy golden pour with white head, aroma brought notes of big vanilla, old coffee grounds, hints of grass, slight bread, biscuit, touch of coffee cream almost. Taste was a mix of grass, biscuit, right into lots of old coffee grounds, vanilla, slight fruit, hints of grain, finishing slightly sweet.

Pours a pale yellow with a long-lasting white head. Aroma is coffee and hints of vanilla. Flavor is some coffee and even more subtle vanilla, with a touch of malts. Has a light, crisp body. Pretty good.
Bottled. Shiny golden amber pour - some coffee malts and vanilla. Really reminded me of drinking cream soda, easily the best cream ale Ive ever had.

Sample at Daily Growler Powell during the Pumpkin Carving Party on 10/22/2015. Clear deep golden color with a medium white head that evaporates quickly to a film. Spotty lacing. Aroma of coffee, vanilla and malt. Light-bodied with flavors of roasted coffee, vanilla, malt and wheat. The finish is roasty and sweet with a vanilla coffee aftertaste. Above average overall.
Golden with a small white head. Vanilla and coffee tones. Coffee, malt, vanilla and hops. Medium body with a nice bitter / roasted finish.
Bottle, Brewdog Leicester. Golden with a thin head. Nutty and caramel malts with cream and hints of vanilla. Earthy coffee. Sweet. Interesting.
On tap at the flying dog. Clear golden with small white head. Aroma is sweet malty, vanilla, coffee and perfume. Taste is similar, loads of coffee and vanilla, some sugar, sweet malt and perfume.

Aroma - not much to report on smell - slight coffee
Appearance - clean honey/gold color body with a big rocky white head that holds for a long time.
Taste - complicated - coffee is the dominant note, some honey malts, wet cardboard, if there is vanilla its not noticeable.
Palate - is the taste associated with drinking old bitter coffee, unpleasant astringency.

Not one of their better beers.
Bottle. Pale copper with small head. Light body, substantial coffee. Creamy. Wish the vanilla was more forward, but this is a nice, tasty beer.

Pours amber yellow with a slight white head. 

Aroma is vanilla and coffee, slight roast.

Taste is moderate roast, sweet vanilla, slight bitter, slight sweet dried fruits

bottle to snifter. ok as I sit here I keep smelling fresh roasted coffee and for the life of me couldnt figure out where it was coming from. then I take a drink and go duh....very good coffee aroma on this cream ale with some caramel and toffee notes. clear light amber color mild carbonation and has a great taste. very smooth and the coffee is not overpowering but you know its there and full of flavor...

Tap at Brewdog Helsinki, Helsinki. Colour is clear orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Some fruits, coffee, vanilla, dryness and malts. Clear.
Bottle at Antenna America, Yokohama. Clear golden - white head. High coffee and vanilla aroma. Light malty taste. Toasted malts. Light citrus. Nice aroma - finishis a bit wierd and thin.
12 ounce bottle. Big coffee nose over a - it doesnt look like a stout - body. Vanilla is prominent. Nice.

Bottle - Pours light amber with a filmy off-white head. Nose is coffee and vanilla without much malt to get in the way. A little corny, a little bready, and the coffee is super mellow and smooth. Good stuff--I love how its just a medium to highlight the coffee and vanilla.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a nice head of dense foam. Aroma is obvious vanilla, sweet, a bit roasty. The flavor is unfortunately overwhelmed by the vanilla and creaminess. Its interesting, but I get turned off quickly.

Bottle:
Clear amber with a thick, off-white head.
Creamy grain malt, vanilla aroma.
Taste is light coffee, vanilla, grains...
Very creamy.....not overly corny....
A really tasty cream ale.......
Thought it was great....wish I had more.
Bottle. Pours clear golden amber with not much head. Nose and taste is artificial vanilla. Coffee. Soap? Pretty good cream ale.

Pours clear amber color with small white head. Smell is coffee and sweet vanilla. Taste is overwhelmingly coffee with hints of vanilla, grass, and malt. Light body and and carbonation. The coffee taste is overpowering and needs a more substantial beer as a base. Overall this sounded really good and fits the deScription, but for me it was a miss.

Draft @ Taproom, Malmö. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty creamy aroma with weak hoppy hints. Fruity malty creamy hoppy vanilla flavor. Has a fruity malty creamy vanilla finish.
bottle from Brewdog online. Pale gold with white head, some visible carbonation. Aroma of coffee and cream. Same for taste. Quite light, quite highly carbonated. Interesting.
12iz bottle @ Doghouse. Clear golden yellow, reasonable head. Vanilla coffee aroma & flavour. Does exactly what it says on the bottle.

Draft at SB. Pours a slightly hazy pale gold with a loose creamy white head that sticks around for quite a while. Does not look remotely like a beer that will contain coffee flavors, but you know how that goes. Nose: Huge roasty coffee notes, some toasty caramel under that. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Clear forward dimensional coffee presence on the mid-palate, starting right from the attack. Long coffee finish.
Bottle at home. Orange colour. Nice coffee and vanilla flavour. Interesting one.

Bottle. The body is a deep amber that is nearly copper. It is topped with a dense off white head. A nose of sweet cereal and a lightly fruity coffee roast. The taste has some rich coffee with notes of slight raisins. There is also some hay and peanuts. A decent drinker that is unique, but not something I would seek out. At least it manages to be strong with coffee without becoming astringent.

5.5%ABV. Cream Ale.

Poured out of the bottle a slightly cloudy deep amber. 14ºSRM.

Nose is dominated by the additives of coffee and vanilla. There is a smoky sweetness to the nose. Like a French roast. There is also a buttery creaminess to the nose.

Mouthfeel is carbonated and sudsy. There is a round fruitiness to the palate which then transitions into a roasty, nutty flavors of graham cracker, toast and nuts like roasted almonds and hazelnuts. This is a well done cream ale with the cream-corn flavor that comes out only after all the other flavors of the additives have vanished. 

The combination of the smoke, vanilla and the chocolate component of the palate all add up to give a recurring and very persistent impression of smores. 

Palate is brief and not very interesting at all. Overall, a very ably put together ale. Good job, guys!
Six pack from Produce Barn. Pours out a light golden color. Frothy off-white head. Unusual aromas and flavors of grassy coffee. Some vanilla notes. Sweet light malts. Strange.

12 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 11/15/15. Pours a mostly clear orange color with an off white head. Sweetened coffee aroma and flavor that has roast and lactose components to it as well. This is smooth, easy drinking beer with a somewhat lively carbonation. It has a bit more of a roast component on the nose than you might expect from a beer that looks like this too. The sweetness works very well without getting cloying. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

12oz bottle from crossroads. Pours out a crystal clear golden Amber color with a thick frothy off white head. Aroma of mainly fresh coffee beans, with hints of vanilla and caramel malt. Taste of light roasted coffee, lemon, grain, and hints of vanilla.

If you like coffee this one delivers. Strong coffee aroma and taste with great ale creaminess. Really enjoyed this one.

Aroma: Earthy and subtle vanilla

Appearance: Clear golden yellow colour and thin creamy head

Taste: Medium sweet like corn syrup and light bitter

Palate: Medium light body, syrupy texture, soft carbonation and the Aroma finishes tenderly, outstanding cream ale.

Kind of an odd duck, but really good. Coffee comes thru strong in aroma with a hint of vanilla. Color is a clear amber. Flavor is this odd mix of beer, coffee and vanilla lasting well into the finish. Great body. Very drinkable beer.
Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle. Aroma is coffee, medium body, low carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is coffee and some cream.

Pours a clear dull-golden with a quickly disappearing white head. Fresh brewed black coffee on the nose. Creamy mouthfeel. Abundant coffee in the flavor all the way to and beyond the finish. A bit of a papery cream soda/seltzer flavor is noted as well.

Clear golden pour with a thin white head and decent sticky lacing .... aroma of fresh coffee and vanilla .... outstanding aroma very fresh ..... taste is of coffee, roasted malts, light vanilla, chocolate malts and caramel malts .... has a slight bitter bite on the back end ..... mouthfeel is creamy .... finish is dry and roasted with a lingering light bitter bite and coffee flavor ..... sessionable and definitely coffee forward

35 cl bottle @ home. Pours clear golden amber with a white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma and flavour are coffee, vanilla, and nuts - with a bitter finish.

Im impressed with this brew overall. Surprised to find it as described...both coffee and vanilla are fully available for taste. I personally still find these flavors much more paltible offered in a stout.

12 Oz bottle. Pours a clear copper caramel with a half finger off white head and fine sediments. Aroma has big notes of drip coffee, espresso, vanilla, and hints of roast and chocolate. Taste is balanced. Vanilla to start, then creamed coffee, bread, caramel, touch of nuttiness, and a medium length ending. Medium body and carbonation. Creamy in the mouth with a slightly dry finish. Overall an easy drinking beer with complexity. Vanilla and roasty coffee throughout mixed with bread, caramel, and a creamy mouth feel.

Aroma: coffee, vanilla
Appearance: orange-gold, white head
Taste: coffee, vanilla, cream

Delicious

Location/Date:Bottle on November 6th, 2015.
Appearance: Pours a light copper orange like cream soda.
Aroma: Aroma of coffee and vanilla.
Taste: Coffee, light vanilla, faint bitterness.
Palate:Medium light, sort of creamy.
Summary: I gotta say I really like this. The coffee and vanilla add nice notes, plenty of flavor for a 5.5% beer. Id gladly buy a six pack of this next time Im at the store.

Bottle. Strong coffee and vanilla caramel malt aroma (did I mention coffee?). Golden yellow with with small head. Sweet creamy vanilla coffee, caramel malt and mildly bitter hay flavor. Nice body. This is one way to improve a cream ale.

Bottle. Ambré with off white head. Aroma of cold coffee, vanilla and dark chocolate. Taste is similar, strong coffee flavour up front then vanilla and chocolate. Clean and slightly bitter. Its arrite but not sure the coffee and shiz belongs here.

Clear orange. Thin white head. Aroma as expected. Here it turns to preference not technical quality. Vanilla notes are ok but boarder on a touch heavy. Coffee simply doesnt work. Too strong to much. Base beer is lost.

Atlanta. Ga. - Tap Gastropub - on tap. Sparkling, medium golden pour, light white head. Aroma of coffee, some roasted vegetable notes. Flavor has some coffee accents, a touch of vanilla, some light citrus bitterness, a topsoil like finish. Crisp mouthfeel. Pretty solid.

Bottle. Nose of dirty vanilla, dirt itself, mild coffee beans [[and porter]]. Really has the smack of a moist dessert cake, one you might find in a shabby off-beat Austrian cafe. Pours deep, rich clear orange with a slow-forming but frothy and oily cream head. Taste dry for attenuation, very faint sweetness rising form the vanilla and the yeast, which still spikes its little esters in there from below, will not be silenced! The portery character is not there like I expected [or perhaps just imagined?], its much more rich/luscious coffee beans that Id mistaken, but the flavor is still quite nice, and the vanilla and coffee are kept to low enough levels that they never grate, never cloy.  True restraint.  Little flecks of orange and lemon here and there, and a medicinal sort of syrup in the deep, deep background, and subtle wisps of caramel and butter for rounding out the feel and the short aftertaste.  Full body but not fat, lightly crisp but not heavy, smooth and moreish despite the gravity, malt is weak but not thin or underthought, and theres a beautiful, balanced melding of three disparate elements (the coffee, the vanilla, and the fruity light cream ale). Phenomenal -- I think Im in love! [2015.10.30: 4.0]

Pours very clear orange gold with not much of a head. Aroma is... odd. Vanilla and coffee. Very unexpected. Taste follow suit and adds a bit of lemon and some hoppiness. Well-described as cream ale + coffee. Active mouthfeel and kind of spicy in terms of sensation. A bit cloying. Somewhat of a misfire from BP - a bit gimmicky.
Absolutely full of coffee, in both its aroma, and especially in taste. Its completely surprising, it tastes dark, but has a clear light orange colour.

Looks solid; a transparent golden orange with white head. Smells of vanilla, mild coffee, and a touch of grain. Tastes like it smells, but more coffee than vanilla, with a medium light-bodied mouthfeel. A nice take on the style
Keg at Brewdog Birmingham; clear amber pour with a thin white head, aroma has a cappuccino, taste has a little kick of coffee along with cream soda, some caramel, nice.

12 oz bottle- Pours dark old golden with a bone white head that mostly sticks around and some layered lace. Aroma is coffee that sneaks up on you, robust, very appealing. The taste is more coffee than i was thinking it would be, and cream, vanilla is strong, all the flavor of a good coffee beer only without the usual dark roasted grains of a porter. Really interesting beer, flavorful, super enjoyable!

12oz bottle pours with a clear deep gold body that has a copper core and supports a thin light tan head. The aroma offers up a good load of dark roasted coffee and then some vague sweeter notes in the background. The taste delivers a pleasing blend of sweet malts linked to a thin ribbon of vanilla that sweeten up the bold dark roasted coffee. It stays dark and toasty with coffee and various sweet notes right into the finish.

33cl bottle at BD camden, London. It pours a clean amber color with a medium white head. Aroma is bready and lightly sweet with lactose, biscuit, roasted malts. Taste has soft melon, sweet malts, milk shake, vanilla and light woody ashy bitterness. Medium bodied with ok carbonation. Overall, ok

Aromas is like cream soda, body is mid golden yellow with a thin cap that leaves some spotty lace Flavor is also like cream soda, the coffee is tucked away but present Overall it was a different spin on a cream ale, but it was good

Pint at Tylers Apex good aroma, sweet, coffee toasty malts, clean golden orange color ok head and lace. Sweet flavor, light body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, sweet finish, thats nice, nice coffee flavor. In a lighter body beer.

Lighter in color than you would expect, but very flavorful. Smells like coffee and tastes like coffee as well. Loved!

Bottle->SA. Clear copper with moderate white head. A: coffee, vanilla, sweet malt, nuts. T: coffee, chocolate, vanilla, lactose. Taste and appearance are really far apart. Interesting.

Bottle in LA. Pale clear amber with tiny fading head. Very big coffee aroma and something smells like chilli. Coffee aroma up front, vanilla on the finish. Medium-high carbonation. Base beer is mild and lets the additions come through. Interesting and enjoyable.
Nice lighter coffee beer. Dark brown color. Seriously dominant coffee. Some vanilla and green pepper too. Lighter. Pretty tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2015 12 oz bottle from Bottles. Aroma consists of coffee, chili peppers (?? possibly coffee beans?), vanilla, awesomeness. Pours clear old gold with a collapsing white head that laces a little. Taste is sweet, finishing dry; flavors like the aroma. Body is thin, a little watery. Never did I think a cream ale could be this interesting. Thank you Ballast Point.

This was a freebie from my favorite liquor store clerk but not something I would have purchased. I love Victory at Sea. I also love most heavy beers. Taking the VAS profile and putting it in a cream ale sounds so logical! But it did not work for me. Strong coffee and vanilla in a light, thin base just didnt do it. Still, its Ballast Point and its worth trying.
On tap at taphouse. Pours out a copper topped with a sand head. Nose is coffee roast creamy and a nice chocolate sweetness. Taste is more of the nice coffee vanilla creamy chocolate.

Location: Bottle from K&L Wine Merchants in Redwood City, CA
Appearance: Light Amber
Aroma: Roasted coffee beans, burnt coffee
Taste: Burnt coffee with fake vanilla syrup
Overall: Definitely not a fan of this style in any way

Bon, ceci est la bière la plus inusité que jai bu de ma vie. Une golden cream ale au café et à la vanille. Achetée à Winooski et recommandée par mon ami Scott (thanks man for this uncommon brew!), la bière est dorée, voire orangée. Même en la versant avec vigueur dans mon verre, je peine à y voir laspect crémeux annoncé. La mousse est bien présente mais mes attentes morientaient davantage vers un truc semblable aux cream ale poussées à lazote. Le problème est sans doute de mon côté mais enfin. Jolis lacings sur le verre. Jusquici tout semble à peu près normal... En approchant le verre de mon nez à la fois intrigué et inquiet, je suis attaqué par de puissants arômes dextraits de vanille! Même si on sy attend, cest déstabilisant, un peu comme lire le mot bleu alors quil est écrit en vert. Il y a quelque-chose qui cloche profondément. À cette vanille artificielle sajoutent des arômes poussiéreuses, terreuses, sucrées et lourdes; un peu à la manière dun mauvais porter. En bouche, le liquide jouit dune belle densité. Jaurais mis ma main à couper quil sagit dun porter dans une vraie dégustation à laveugle. Texture peu soyeuse; voire un peu sèche et râpeuse. La vanille est encore artificielle ici et le café annoncé sur létiquette est des plus discrets. Je peine à le percevoir. Peut-être est-ce simplement car mon cerveau refuse de le reconnaître dans une bière de cette clareté. Bref, cette bière est très intéressante pour lexpérience sensorielle quelle procure. Est-elle bonne? Je ne crois pas. Je demeure toute de même très heureux davoir confronté mes sens à un liquide si... unique!
Bottle at home. Pours clear amber, nose is toffee, coffee, vanilla, taste is sweet, creamy, dry roasted, not entirely sure the coffee works.

Bottle. Pours a dark gold with a medium, fine-grained, off-white head. Nose, is coffee, vanilla, apple, turbinado sugar, and biscuity grain. I would not have thought you could mix these flavors and this style, but this beer pulls it off. Finish is clean and sharp. Very nicely done.

Appearance- Clear amber with a fluffy white head, not long lasting and with little lacing.
Aroma- Caramel malt, coffee, smoky.

Golden color or light, light orange. Thick shaving cream head. From the label, I assumed it would be black or brown, but no dice.

The first sniff is dry, dusty iced coffee. Touch of hazelnut. Vanilla sticks, the dry kind, not the milky kind you may think of. There is a touch of "skunk" but I mean actual skunk, not skunked beer. 

The first sip, like the aroma, is cold coffee. The vanilla is an accent, but its dominated by mocha and coffee grounds. Its almost like when you brew a cup of coffee and it still has some of the grounds at the bottom and you swallow some of them, without the grit of course. The "cream ale" part is a distant third, with a touch of corn sugars. 

Feel is creamy slickness. This may be the new trend in the next year: a pale ale with dark flavors like coffee and vanilla. There is a bit of cognitive dissonance in looking at it and then sipping it.

Coffee and vanilla are flavor additives you usually associated with a stout or porter. But with Calm Before the Storm, Ballast Point shows these ingredients can work just as well in a lighter brew. Its interesting that they went with a cream ale to try this with, though its rather moot since the base brew really is overshadowed by the coffee and vanilla. You might consider this a novelty beer, but I consider it a good beer.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 7/13/15 and cost $3.85 ($0.32 per ounce).

Appearance: Surprisingly dark copper/amber hue (its golden on the brewerys website); pours to a small, ivory, foamy head which doesnt retain or lace all that well.

Smell: A sweet iced coffee scent; I can actually detect a bit of corn, too. They dont clash, though.

Taste: This beer is intended to be a warmer weather alternative to an imperial stout brewed with the same flavors. Its certainly an interesting choice and it does work pretty well. The coffee is evident immediately, but its not deeply roasted and extremely bitter; more of an iced coffee with sugar and cream. The vanilla gives it a bit of a chocolate candy flavor. I dont detect the base brew until the finish when a bit of corn emerges. At first its an odd, slightly distracting flavor, but I get used to it quickly. Only a mild bitterness on the backend with a slight drying sensation. It doesnt get any more complex than this, but these flavors are enjoyable enough to make for a good beer.

Drinkability: I was a bit surprised to see Ballast Point Calm Before The Storm was only 5.5% ABV. I was expecting this to be a stronger brew. The mouthfeel is a bit calm and a little thinner than Id prefer. Its crisp as it goes down and theres only a mild iced coffee aftertaste which eventually fades completely. I would not consider it refreshing, nor would I consider it so richly sweet that it works as a dessert beer (at least not on its own). 

RATING: 8/10

8oz pour at malt and vine, golden pour looks like a IPA, aroma full of espresso, nice body not to overwhelming, little sweet coffee on the finish.
Interesting brew. Pours straw / orange with a white head. Aroma is primarily coffee with notes of vanilla. Finishes with notes of cold coffee and vanilla.
Smell like a cup of coffee and cream. Very clear light orange little head. Smooth cup of coffee with light cream. Tricks you with its looks super smooth cup of coffee excellence.

Clear copper color with a medium head. Solid coffee aroma, with a bit of corn and lactose. Flavor is predominantly coffee, with light apple and citrus. Definitely some grainy corn character. Dry finish.

355ml bottle. Gold pour with a large but quickly dissipating head. Coffee and cream aroma, reminds me of another beer Ive had but cant remember which one. Flavor is sweet with a coffee note and some biscuit. This is actually really taste unlike the goose island coffee golden ale.

Pours a clear brown from a bottle, aroma of caramel, coffee, vanilla. Flavor similar, rather thin and somewhat soda-like. A little off-putting. Havent had Victory at Sea, so not sure how it compares, but almost not looking forward to it now if it inspired this. Meh.

12oz bottle from Andersons in Dublin: murky gold pour with thin white head. aroma of roasted coffee and vanilla. tastes are sweet nutty, vanilla, coffee. interesting, but never been a fan of the style.

Draught. Pours clear golden colour with a mostly fading off white head. Aroma of coffee, cappuccino flavours, loads of vanilla, milk chocolate, oats. Taste is of coffee, cream, vanilla, oats, woody notes. Light oily body, soft carbonation.

My nre favorite in the cream ale style (which already belonged to Ballast Point anyway)...but because of the coffee part, not the cream part. A touch hoppier than expected, but the vanilla and lactose show nicely as it warms. As expected, coffee is the star of the show and is done well. a treat.
Smells spicy, like there is a pepper in it or something. No spice in the flavor, but the vanilla is dominant.

Pours copper orange with a small white head. Head retention is ok. AROMA, medium roasted coffee, vanilla coffee creamer, slight floral hops, malt, coffee house, light citrus, spice and peppermint candy. TASTE: vanilla coffee creamer, light coffee bitterness, malty, spice, hop bitterness, slight citrus, mellow peppermint candy and light salted pretzel. AFTER TASTE: coffee bitterness, hop spice, vanilla extract and light citrus with an oily buttery finish.

On tap at Dutchs. Clear golden orange color. Thin slightly off-white head, with good retention. Leaves great, thicker lace. Very impressive coffee up front, some vanilla. Nice kind of cereal-like grain. Big coffee, some vanilla, but still, refreshing despite that, which is impressive. Medium body. Smooth, kind of crisp lighter carbonation. Mild dry in the finish. Good, sort of creamy fullness to the mouthfeel. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, seems like a little added bitterness from the coffee, not that I mind. Light sweet. Just a very mild roasty roughness on the back end. Overall, very tasty. This kind of thing appeals to me. Big coffee, yet refreshing and easy to sip. Not too sweet at all.

Bottle shared by Keith, Pours Clearish golden color, Notes are vanilla and espresso bean with some marshmallow fluff and other lactose like flavors. Light bodied, and refreshing with lots of rich coffee. Not bad.

Pours bright golden/copper color with white head. Aroma is earthy, roasted coffee, and vanilla. Flavor is big roasted coffee up front with some earthiness and smokiness, followed by vanilla and cream soda. Finishes creamy coffee.

P: A golden caramel color with a one finger white head. S: Starts of with cream and lactose, a big roast of coffee jumps through, with a bit of caramel in the back. T: Lots of coffee, vanilla, caramel, and cream soda. M: Creamy with a medium body a and light roast in the end. O: A bit artificial but I cant lie, I enjoyed it and it was what label said it would be.

Draft to taster at Dutchs. Looks solid; a transparent golden orange with white head. Smells of vanilla, mild coffee, and a touch of grain. Tastes like it smells, but more coffee than vanilla, with a medium light-bodied mouthfeel. A nice take on the style.
Pours light gold with no head. Aroma of coffee, cream and caramel. Taste follows, like coffee with cream. Really tasty

Pours a super clear golden with a decent white head. Aroma is light roast coffee, a touch of vanilla, like an iced coffee. Taste is similar with a big coffee hit up front that slides to a vanilla and finished with hazelnut. Really good beer. Surprisingly refreshing.

12 oz. bottle. Pour a clear golden color with a tight foamy soapy head that fades to a film. Aroma is strong coffee vanilla. Taste follows suit with the coffee and vanilla very nice up front, but the lightness is very erie, yet has a creaminess that smooths the flavors. Its not bad, just so used to dark high alcohol brews with these flavors.

12oz. Smells great, sounds great, but doesnt fully come through. They do say that they were going for light here though and that is right on. Nice vanillad coffee lingering notes in the finish. Refreshing almost. Could be louder but decent.

>> Clear orange pour, weak foam. Intense aroma of hazelnut coffee with macadamia creamer Taste is a bit soda like, cream soda, small lemon, paper, sweet vanilla. Not my thing, but probably will become popular.

The skeleton at the wheel label and the name of the beer are a thumbs up. Amaretto aroma, light brown appearance with little head and oily lacing
soft and whispy, swirling in the mouth leaves some creamy vanilla taste
light and wimpy Gimme the storm already, Freddie 
Victory. Sculpin. Those are two strong BP offerings.
Nose is Cheerios, coffee and vanilla. Flavor is same but there is a little too much astringency and a misplaced bitterness.

Pours a light copper to an amber color. Aroma of coffee and a slight pepper smell. Taste is vanilla, coffee, and a caramel sweetness. A light creaminess to the beer, which coats the tongue but then quickly dissipates. No distinct aftertaste, enjoyable but not complex.

Aromas of fake coffee, fake espresso, coffee oils, caramel, earth, biscuit and some funky malt twang. Appearance is gold with a thin white foam. Taste is creamy with caramel, vanilla, coriander, citrus, odd mocha coffee notes and a faint almond. Overall, this is a real big disappointment from Ballast Point. Its so disjointed and artificial tasting. Its just a huge mess.

I found this odd it has coffee but was golden in color. Vanilla is quite noticeable and goes very well with the vanilla. It was definitely unique and I didnt dislike it, but it has a taste that would take some getting used to. For an experimental, this is a great effort.
Bottle. Pours a rich, clear amber with thin dissipating head. Nose of peppers, coffee, light sweetness. Taste is the same, bright mouthfeel, little sweet, little watery. Drinkable, but not my style.

Bottle from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours a darkish gold that is a bit unusual, and the white head was slight and transient. Aroma is quite coffee! Almost med body. Flavor is a nutty coffee. Seems to have some bitter, but that may be from coffee. Not identifying any particular hoplike flavors. Its an eye opener. Surprised Mikk didnt steal this and label it "Breakfast Geek Cream Ale" or similar.

Pours a clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma has awesome fresh coffee...lightly roasted. Flavor follows suit and adds a touch of vanilla and some nuttiness...deceptive and tasty. Mouthfeel is light / medium and the finish is dry and grassy lingering to roasty coffee.
Surprisingly delicious, kind of the ice coffee version of their Porter, Victory At Sea. Highly recommend!
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Rich coffee and vanilla, light pale malty base, relatively low sweetness, and low bitterness. Pretty good.
Tap, gold pour, white head, nose and taste are creamy, bitter, citrus, go team go
